Reid: Brown 'one of the most partisan' in Senate

"I saw during the campaign [Scott Brown's] plea for bipartisanship. That is a big joke. It's a travesty," the Senate majority leader told reporters. (Globe, 4:59 p.m.)

Co-owner of Framingham firm pleads 5th

Co-owner appears at congressional panel

Barry Cadden, co-owner of the Framingham pharmacy linked to a meningitis outbreak, refused to answer questions at a congressional hearing. (Globe, 11:55 a.m.)

Obama addresses 'fiscal cliff', Libya attacks during press conference

In a wide-ranging news conference today, the president took time to rebut GOP charges that the American public was misled on the attacks in Libya. (Globe, 5:33 p.m.)

Romney: Federal 'gifts' to young voters, minorities helped Obama win reelection

The losing candidate for president said the gifts included guaranteed health care coverage, help paying for college, and protection from deportation. (Globe, 6:15 p.m.)

Greig wants new hearing without input from relatives of Bulger's alleged victims

Catherine E. Greig asked a federal court to shorten her eight-year prison sentence and bar relatives of alleged victims from speaking at a hearing. (Globe, 3:45 p.m.)

Health & Wellness

Can meditation reduce your risk of having a heart attack or stroke?

In a new study, heart patients who were randomly assigned to practice meditation every day for five years were 48 percent less likely to die or have a heart attack or stroke compared with their counterparts.
